	mso-bidi-language:#0400;}
</style>
<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="4098"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US link="#009999" vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>Problem I</span></b><span style='font-family:
Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>In-Ellipse
</span></b><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'><br>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Input: </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Standard Input<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard
Output <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>An in-ellipse of a triangle is an
ellipse which touches all the sides of the triangle internally. In the figure
below you can see a triangle ABC and one of its axis parallel in-ellipse.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype
 id="_x0000_t75" coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t"
 path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe" filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:366pt;
 height:243.75pt'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/i_files/image001.png"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=488 height=325
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/i_files/image001.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:normal'>Given the coordinate
of vertices of a triangle, your job is to find that axis parallel in-ellipse.
Note that any axis-parallel in-ellipse can be expressed uniquely with an
equation of the following form:<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
font-weight:normal'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape id="_x0000_i1026" type="#_x0000_t75"
 style='width:141pt;height:41.25pt' o:ole=" >
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/i_files/image001.png"  o:title=" />
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=188 height=55
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/i_files/image001.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1026"><![endif]><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="Equation.3" ShapeID="_x0000_i1026"
  DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1314080940">
 </o:OLEObject>
</xml><![endif]--><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:normal'>Here (h, k) is the
center of the ellipse (Intersection point of major and minor axis) and 2a is
the length of the major axis and 2b is the length of the minor axis. So an
axis-parallel ellipse can be uniquely described with four parameters h, k, <span
class=GramE>a and</span> b. For this problem b can be greater than a.<o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";font-weight:normal'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Input</span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Arial Unicode MS";mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The input file contains at most
10001 lines of inputs. Each line contains seven floating-point numbers x<sub>1</sub>,
y<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>, y<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>3</sub>, y<sub>3</sub>, <span
class=SpellE>El_A</span>. The first six floating-point numbers denote that the
three vertices of the triangle in counter-clockwise order are (x<sub>1</sub>, y<sub>1</sub>),
(x<sub>2</sub>, y<sub>2</sub>) and (x<sub>3</sub>, y<sub>3</sub>). The seventh
floating-point number <span class=SpellE>El_A</span> denotes the <span
class=SpellE>the</span> area of in-ellipse of this triangle. Note that (0 &#8804;
x<sub>1</sub>, y<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>, y<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>3</sub>, y<sub>3
</sub>&#8804; 5000) and (0&lt;<span class=SpellE>El_A</span>&lt;1000000). Input
is terminated by a line where the given area of the in-ellipse is negative.
This line should not be processed.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h4><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Output </span></span><span
class=StyleArial16pt><span style='mso-ansi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'>For each line
of input produce one line of output. This line contains four floating-point
numbers. These numbers denote the value of h, k, <span class=GramE>a and</span>
b of the desired (Axis parallel in-ellipse of the given triangle and having
area <span class=SpellE>El_A</span>) ellipse. All these floating-point numbers
should have ten (10) digits after the decimal point. For every input there will
be a solution. If there is more than one solution, any one will be accepted.
There is <span class=GramE>an</span> special judge to ignore small precision
errors. Also the value of a/b should be within 0.1 and 10 to not allow ellipses
that are almost straight <span class=GramE>line </span><span style='font-family:
Wingdings;mso-ascii-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-hansi-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-char-type:symbol;mso-symbol-font-family:Wingdings'><span style='mso-char-type:
symbol;mso-symbol-font-family:Wingdings'>J</span></span>. </p>

<h1><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=697
 style='width:522.9pt;background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;
 mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=697 valign=top style='width:522.9pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>97.6419300000 2129.1127667152 155.3286100000
  1702.4002779560 385.0688800000 748.0494778467 1781.9759297640<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>138.7581800000 246.7354898358
  352.2499900000 197.8134603618 54.2186200000 300.6027786815 423.6516437136<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:8.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>1727.1587740317 349.0465400000
  479.4245277302 84.8220300000 1561.3000471558 179.7437900000 -44.3989182783<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h1><span style='font-size:16.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Arial;
mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>Output for Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:
 solid windowtext .5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=649 valign=top style='width:486.9pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>165.0883167048 1730.5402621884
  11.9500482151 47.4659637479<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>143.3157614522 257.5968732740
  11.6210876787 11.6041209071<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:Verdana'>Problem setter:
Shahriar <span class=SpellE>Manzoor</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

class=SpellE>Kisman</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></p>

  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->

<body lang=EN-US link=blue vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Problem J</span></b><span
style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:Arial'><br>
</span><b><span style='font-size:20.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:
Arial'>Happy Friends</span></b><b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;font-family:
Arial'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Input: </span></b><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard
Input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial'>Output: </span></b><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>Standard
Output </span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:
18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The happiness of your friends makes
you happier, and this increase of your happiness also has impact on your
friends' happiness. What if no other effect (like dissatisfaction, poverty,
enmity etc.) exits? The happiness would always increase day by day in a
friendship network.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Can you help to analyze the
scenario if only happiness exists in a friendship network? You are given a
friendship network of N friends. You can identify them by integers from 0 to N
- 1. You are also given M pairs of integer. Each pair represents a friendship
between two persons in that network. You are also given a person who is the
first happy person in the network. The initial degree of happiness of that
first person is 1. Initial degree of happiness of all others in that friendship
network is 0. The network will be given in such a way that each persons degree
of happiness will be affected after a certain period by the initial happy
person.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Can you answer, what will be the
degree of happiness of all of N persons in that network after D days if the
degree of happiness of each person increases by a defined rule?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The only simple rule is - Each
day, a person's degree of happiness is increased if and only if his degree of
happiness is not increased in previous day. If the degree of happiness is not
increased in previous day then it will increased by the summation of degree of
happiness of all of his friends at previous day.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>To make it more clear, let us
consider a person p, and his degree of happiness is not increased at <span
class=SpellE>d<sup>th</sup></span> day, so his degree of happiness will
increase at (d+1)<span class=SpellE><sup>th</sup></span> day by the summation
of degree of happiness of all of his friends at <span class=SpellE>d<sup>th</sup></span>
day. But if his degree of happiness increased at <span class=SpellE>d<sup>th</sup></span>
day, it will remain same after (d+1<span class=GramE>)<span class=SpellE><sup>th</sup></span></span>
day.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Input</span></b><b><span style='font-family:Arial'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Input will start with an integer <span
class=GramE>T(</span>1 &#8804; T &#8804; 200), number of test cases. Each case
starts with four integers <span class=GramE>N(</span>1 &#8804; N &#8804; 30),
M(N-1 &#8804; M &#8804; N*(N-1)/2), K(0 &#8804; K &#8804; N-1) and D(0 &#8804; D
&#8804; 1000000000), number of nodes, number of friendships, initial happy
person and number of days. Each of the next M lines will contain two integers u
and <span class=GramE>v(</span>0 &#8804; u, v &#8804; N-1, <span class=SpellE>u&#8800;v</span>),
which represents that u and v are friends. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
font-family:Arial'>Output</span></b><b><span style='font-family:Arial'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For each test case output a
single line providing the case number followed by N space separated integers. The
<span class=SpellE>i<sup>th</sup></span> integer represents the degree of happiness
of <span class=SpellE>i<sup>th</sup></span> person after D days.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>The degree of happiness can be very large so
that you should output the value of degree of happiness modulo 1000000007.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>See sample input and output for exact format.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<h1 align=left style='text-align:left'><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Arial;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
font-style:normal'>Sample Input<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                          </span>Output for Sample
Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='background:#CCCCCC;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:
 solid windowtext .5pt;mso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=307 valign=top style='width:3.2in;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:
  "Courier New"'>2<br>
  2 1 0 <span class=SpellE>0</span><br>
  0 1<br>
  4 3 0 3<br>
  0 1<br>
  1 2<br>
  2 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=309 valign=top style='width:231.85pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
  style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'>Case 1:
  1 0<br>
  Case 2: 2 4 1 <span class=SpellE>1</span><o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
  mso-bidi-font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:304.75pt'><!--[if mso & !supportInlineShapes & supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin;mso-field-lock:yes'></span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>SHAPE <span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span>\* MERGEFORMAT <span style='mso-element:field-separator'></span><![endif]--><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:rect
 id="_x0000_s1026" style='width:494.45pt;height:1.5pt;

 v-text-anchor:middle' fillcolor="#aca899" stroked="f">
 <v:fill color2="#535766"/>
 <v:stroke joinstyle="round"/>
 <w:wrap type="none"/>
 <w:anchorlock/>
</v:rect><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=659 height=2
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/j_files/image001.gif"  v:shapes="_x0000_s1026"><![endif]><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Deadly Atack</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Deadly Atack">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Deadly Atack</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Since the King of Nlogonia built, decades earlier, an enormous protecting wall around the whole kingdom, its inhabitants have lived safely. The wall is massive, extremely reinforced, and has the format of a circle, enclosing all the King's domains. 

<P>
However, in recent weeks inhabitants of Nlogonia are upset. There are rumors that scientists from Quadradonia, a barbaric nation in Nlogonia's neighborhood, have developed a lethal weapon, capable of blowing away anything on its reach. 

<P>
The new weapon is a cannon that emits a beam of protons that spread with an angle  from the cannon's mouth. The beam's direction is determined by an angle , measured counterclockwise from the x axis. The figure below illustrates (a) an example of an atack, (b) what would remain from Nlogonia and (c) the area that would be destroyed.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">

<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p11676.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="727" HEIGHT="250" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p11676.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Given the cannon's coordinates, the beam's direction and spread angle, as well as the coordinate of the wall's center and radius, you must write a program to calculate the area of Nlogonia that will be destroyed.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains several test cases. Each test case is composed by two lines. The first line contains three integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>X</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Y</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>R</I></SPAN>, with <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>X</I>, <I>Y</I>)</SPAN> representing the coordinates of the protection wall's center (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le X \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>X</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $0 \le Y \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>Y</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>), and radius (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le R \le 100$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>R</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100</SPAN>). The second line contains four integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>P</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Q</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN>, with <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>P</I>, <I>Q</I>)</SPAN> representing the cannon's coordinates (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le P \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>P</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $0 \le Q \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>Q</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>), <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> representing the beam's direction, in degrees (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le A  359$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>A</I><IMG
  WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
   SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
    ALT="$ \le$">359</SPAN>), and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> representing the spread angle, also in degrees (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le T \le 179$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>T</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11676.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">179</SPAN>). The angle A is measured counter-clockwise from the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> axis, and the cannon is always outside the protecting wall. 

<P>
The end of input is indicated by a line which contains three zeros, separated by single spaces.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case in the input your program should print a single line, containing a real number, written with a precision of one decimal place, indicating the area of Nlogonia that would be destroyed by the atack.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
1 1 1
3 1 180 90
4 4 3
8 4 90 90
4 4 3
8 4 180 179
0 0 0 0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
3.1
0.2
28.3
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Alarm Clock</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Alarm Clock">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Alarm Clock</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Daniela is a nurse in a large hospital, which causes her working shifts to constantly change. To make it worse, she has deep sleep, and a difficult time to wake up using alarm clocks. 

<P>
Recently she got a digital clock as a gift, with several different options of alarm sounds, and she has hope that it might help solve her problem. But, lately, she's been very tired and want to enjoy every single moment of rest. So she carries her new clock to every place she goes, and whenever she has some spare time, she tries to sleep, setting her alarm clock to the time when she needs to wake up. But, with so much anxiety to sleep, she ends up with some difficulty to fall asleep and enjoy some rest. 

<P>
A problem that has been tormenting her is to know how many minutes of sleep she would have if she felt asleep immediately and woken up when the alarm clock ringed. But she is not very good with numbers, and asked you for help to write a program that, given the current time and the alarm time, find out the number of minutes she could sleep.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains several test cases. Each test case is described in one line, containing four integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN>, with <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I><SUB>1</SUB> : <I>M</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> representing the current hour and minute, and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>H</I><SUB>2</SUB> : <I>M</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN> representing the time (hour and minute) when the alarm clock is set to ring (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le H_1 \le 23$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>H</I><SUB>1</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">23</SPAN>, <!-- MATH
 $0 \le M_1 \le 59$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>M</I><SUB>1</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">59</SPAN>, <!-- MATH
 $0 \le H_2 \le  23$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>H</I><SUB>2</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">23</SPAN>, <!-- MATH
 $0 \le  M_2 \le  59$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>M</I><SUB>2</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11677img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">59</SPAN>). 

<P>
The end of the input is indicated by a line containing only four zeros, separated by blank spaces.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case, your program must print one line, containing a single integer, indicating the number of minutes Daniela has to sleep. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
1 5 3 5
23 59 0 34
21 33 21 10
0 0 0 0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
120
35
1417
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Exchanging Cards</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Exchanging Cards">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Exchanging Cards</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Alice and Betty collect Pok´mon cards. The cards are printed for a game that imitates the e battle system of one of the most popular videogames in history, but Alice and Betty are too young to actually play the game, and are only interested in the actual cards. To make it easier, we'll assume each card has an unique identifier, given as an integer number. 

<P>
Both girls have a set of cards, and, like most girls their age, like to trade the cards they have. They obviously don't care about identical cards they both have, and they don't want to receive repeated cards in the trade. Besides, the cards are traded in a single operation: Alice gives Betty <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> distinct cards and receives back other <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> distinct cards. 

<P>
The girls want to know what is the maximum number of cards they can trade. For instance, if Alice has cards {1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 8, 8, 9, 15} and Betty has cards {2, 2, 2, 3, 4, 6, 10, 11, 11}, they can trade at most four cards. 

<P>
Write a program that given the sets of cards owned by Alice and Betty, determines the maximum number of cards they can trade.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains several test cases. The first line of a test case contains two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN>, separated by a blank space, indicating respectively the number of cards Alice and Betty have (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  A \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>A</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $1 \le  B \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>B</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN>). The second line contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> space-separated integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>X</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>, each indicating one of Alice's cards (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  X_i \le  10^5$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>X</I><SUB>i</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>5</SUP></SPAN>). The third line contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Y</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> separated by whitespaces, each number indicating one of Betty's cards (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  Y_i \le  10^5$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>Y</I><SUB>i</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11678img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>5</SUP></SPAN>). Alice and Betty's cards are listed in non-descending order. 

<P>
The end of input is indicated by a line containing only two zeros, separated by a blank space.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case, your program should print a single line, containing an integer number, indicating the maximum number of cards Alice and Betty can trade. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
1 1
1000
1000
3 4
1 3 5
2 4 6 8
10 9
1 1 2 3 5 7 8 8 9 15
2 2 2 3 4 6 10 11 11
0 0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
0
3
4
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Sub-prime</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Sub-prime">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Sub-prime</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
The most recent economic crisis was partly caused by the manner in which banks made loans to people unable to repay them and resold such loans to other banks as debentures. Obviously, when people failed to repay their loans, the whole system collapsed. 

<P>
The crisis was so deep that it affected countries all over the world, including Nlogonia, where the honored prime minister Man Dashuva ordered the Central Bank chairman to come up with a solution. He came up with a brilliant idea: if all banks could liquidate its debentures only with its own monetary reserves, all banks would survive and the crisis would be averted. 

<P>
However, with the elevated number of debentures and banks involved, this was an extremely complicated task, so he asked for your help in writing a program that, given the banks and the debentures printed by them, determines if it is possible that all banks pay back their debts using only their monetary reserves and credits.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input consists of several test cases. The first line of each test case contains two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>, indicating the number of banks (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  B \le  20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>B</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN>) and the number of debentures printed by the banks (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  N \le  20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN>). The banks are identified by integers between 1 and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN>. The second line contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>R</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN> separated by spaces, indicating the monetary reserves of each one of the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> banks (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le  R_i \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>R</I><SUB>i</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN>, for <!-- MATH
 $1 \le  i \le  B$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>i</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>B</I></SPAN>). The <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> following lines contain each one three integers separated by spaces: an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>D</I></SPAN>, indicating the debtor bank (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  D \le  B$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>D</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>B</I></SPAN>), an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>C</I></SPAN> , indicating the creditor bank (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  C \le  B$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>C</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>B</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>D</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="34" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \ne$"><I>C</I></SPAN>) and an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>V</I></SPAN>, indicating the debenture value (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  V \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>V</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11679img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN>). 

<P>
The end of input is indicated by a line containing only two zeros, separated by spaces.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case, your program should print a single line, containing a single character: `<TT>S</TT>', if it is possible to liquidate all debentures without a bailout from the Central Bank of Nlogonia, or `<TT>N</TT>' if a bailout is necessary.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
3 3
1 1 1
1 2 1
2 3 2
3 1 3
3 3
1 1 1
1 2 1
2 3 2
3 1 4
3 3
1 1 1
1 2 2
2 3 2
3 1 2
0 0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
S
N
S
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

11680||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2008 (1.71)

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Dragster</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Dragster">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Dragster</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Dragster racing is not very popular in Brazil, but it attracts crowds in the USA. The fans enjoy seeing cars racing at speeds up to 250 mph, even if only for a few seconds. Many competitors are amateur mechanics that just attached rockets and other contraptions to create ultra-fast cars. 

<P>
Dragster competitions are elimination tournaments, where each confrontation consists of two competitors racing side by side and only one of them being declared the winner (the fastest one, obviously). The winners are then rematched into new races, until only one competitor remains - which is declared the winner. 

<P>
Rubens is an experienced pilot, with a racing career in several categories, including Formula 1. However, after facing some difficulties, he decided to dedicate himself to dragster racing. Using his vast experience from Formula 1, he can, observing the competitors, tell what is the probability each one would prevail during a race between any pair of them. 

<P>
Even though Rubens is a good pilot, he's not very good in math nor computing, so he asked your help to write a program that, given the probabilities computed by Rubens for all races between each pair of pilots, and the description of the tournament structure, determines his proability of winning the tournament.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input consists of several test cases. The first line of a test case contains a single integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>, indicating the number of competitors in this tournament (<!-- MATH
 $2 \le  N \le  300$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">2<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">300</SPAN>). In the tournament descripton, each competitor is identified by an integer from 1 to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>, and the races are identified by integers from <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> + 1</SPAN> to <!-- MATH
 $2 \times N - 1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">2 <TT>x</TT> <I>N</I> - 1</SPAN>. Rubens is always identified by the number 1. The <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> next lines describe the probability matrix computed by Rubens. The <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN>-th line contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> real numbers 
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I>[<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>]</SPAN> separated by spaces (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le  M [i, j ] \le  1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>M</I>[<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>]<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1</SPAN>, for <!-- MATH
 $1 \le  i \le  N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>i</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I></SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $1 \le  j \le  N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>j</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I></SPAN>). Each matrix entry 
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I>[<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>]</SPAN> indicates the probability of competitor <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN> winning a race against competitor <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>j</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $0.001 \le  M [i, j ] \le  0.999$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0.001<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>M</I>[<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>]<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">0.999</SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $M [i, j ] + M [j, i] = 1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I>[<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>] + <I>M</I>[<I>j</I>, <I>i</I>] = 1</SPAN> for <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="34" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \ne$"><I>j</I></SPAN> , and <!-- MATH
 $M [i, j ] = 0$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>M</I>[<I>i</I>, <I>j</I>] = 0</SPAN> for <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I> = <I>j</I></SPAN>). The probabilities will always be given with three decimal places. Each one of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> - 1</SPAN> lines contains two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN>, describing a race. <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> are race or competitor identifiers (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  A \le  2 \times N - 1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>A</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">2 <TT>x</TT> <I>N</I> - 1</SPAN> e <!-- MATH
 $1 \le  B \le  2 \times N - 1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>B</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/11680img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">2 <TT>x</TT> <I>N</I> - 1</SPAN>). The first of these lines describes race <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> + 1</SPAN>, the next line describes race <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> + 2</SPAN>, and so on. When a race identifier <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> appears in the input as <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN>, that means the winner of race <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> will run against <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN>; similarly, when a race identifier <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> appears as <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN>, the winner of race <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>k</I></SPAN> will run against <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN>. 

<P>
The end of input is indicated by a line containing a single zero.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case inthe input, your program should print a single line, containing a single real number, with six decimal places precision, indicating the probability of Rubens winning the tournament.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
4
0.000 0.500 0.400 0.400
0.500 0.000 0.500 0.500
0.600 0.500 0.000 0.600
0.600 0.500 0.400 0.000
1 2
3 4
5 6
5
0.000 0.500 0.600 0.600 0.001
0.500 0.000 0.500 0.500 0.500
0.400 0.500 0.000 0.500 0.500
0.400 0.500 0.500 0.000 0.500
0.999 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.000
3 8
9 6
4 5
1 2
0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
0.200000
0.225125
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Towers for Mobile Telephony</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Towers for Mobile Telephony">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Towers for Mobile Telephony</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
A new telephony company intends to offer services of residential telephone in your city. The phones will be residential, but the company will use mobile tecnology, with transmitter towers, to avoid the expenses of building a cable network throughout the city. 

<P>
The power of the equipment installed in a tower defines the tower's <EM>cover radius</EM> (which, in turn, defines the cover area of the tower, since the city is perfeclty flat). The cost of the equipment installed in each tower is directly proportional to its power, and therefore to its cover radius. 

<P>
The company decided that exactly two towers will be used. The same type of equipment will be installed in both towers; that is, both towers will have the same cover radius. Since the company wants to offer its services to all homes in the city, the cover radius of both towers, together, must cover all homes. Additionally, to minimize the cost, the cover radius of the towers must be the minimum possible. The figure below shows two possible configurations of cover radius for the two towers in a city with ten homes. Both (a) and (b) cover all homes, but (b) is the one that uses the minimum possible cover radius.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p11681.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="657" HEIGHT="230" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11681.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p11681.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Given the position of each home in the city, you must write a program to determine the smallest cover radius for the towers, so that all homes in the city are covered.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains several test cases. Each test case is composed by two lines. The first line of a test case contains an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>, the number of homes in the city (<!-- MATH
 $3 \le  N \le  40$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">3<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11681.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11681.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">40</SPAN>). Each of the following <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> lines contains two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>X</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Y</I></SPAN>, separated by a single space (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le  X \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11681.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>X</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11681.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN> e <!-- MATH
 $0 \le  Y \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11681.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>Y</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11681.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN>), representing the position of a home. Each home has a different position. 

<P>
The end of input is indicated by a line containing only one zero.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case in the input your program must print a single line, containing a real number, written with a precision of two decimal places, indicating the smallest cover radius to be used in both towers.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
3
0 0
1 0
0 4
10
0 0
0 3
1 6
2 2
3 5
5 3
6 3
9 5
10 5
11 3
0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
0.50
3.05
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Shift Register</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Shift Register">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Shift Register</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
A <EM>shift register</EM> is a circuit that shifts the elements of a bit array by one position. A shift register has an input (one bit) and an output (also one bit), and is driven by a clock pulse. When the clock pulse happens, the input bit is shifted to the position of the least significant bit, the most significant bit is sent to the register output, and all other bits are shifted by one position to the direction of the array's most significant bit (towards the output). 

<P>
A <EM>Linear Feedback Shift Register</EM> (<SMALL>LFSR</SMALL>) is a shift register in which the input bit is determined by the value of the <SMALL>EXCLUSIVE-OR</SMALL> of some of the register bits before the clock pulse. The bits that are used in the register's feedback are called taps. The figure below shows a <SMALL>LFSR</SMALL> with 8 bits and three taps (bits 0,3 and 5).

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p11682.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="610" HEIGHT="309" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11682.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p11682.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
In this problem you must write a program that, given the number of bits of a <SMALL>LFSR</SMALL>, the information of which of its bits are taps, a start state and a final state, determines how many clock pulses are needed so that, starting from the start state, the <SMALL>LFSR</SMALL> reaches the final state (or determines that that is impossible).

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains several test cases. Each test case is composed by three lines. The first line contains two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN>, indicating respectively the number of bits (<!-- MATH
 $2 \le  N \le  32$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">2<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11682.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11682.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">32</SPAN>) and the number of taps (<!-- MATH
 $2 \le  T \le  N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">2<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11682.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>T</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11682.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I></SPAN>). The bits are identified by integers from 0 (least significant) to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> - 1</SPAN> (most significant). The second line contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>T</I></SPAN> integers, separated by spaces, describing the bits that are taps, in increasing order. Bit 0 is always a tap. The third line contains two numbers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>I</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>F</I></SPAN> in hexadecimal notation, separated by a blank space, representing respectively the start state and the final state of the <SMALL>LFSR</SMALL>.

<P>
The end of input is indicated by a line that contains two zeros separated by a blank space.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case in the input your program must print a single line. If it is possible to reach the final state from the given start state, the line must contain a single integer, the smallest
number of clock pulses needed for the lfsr to reach the final state given. If that is not the case, the line must contain just the character `<TT>*</TT>'.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
8 3
0 3 5
a9 35
5 2
0 4
1b 2
7 3
0 2 3
4d 1a
0 0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
3
*
61
</PRE> 

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
11683||||||false||||||

* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Laser Sculpture</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Laser Sculpture">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2008">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0000ff><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#FFff00>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Laser Sculpture</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>
Since its invention, in 1958, the laser has been used in a huge variety of applications, like electronic equipment, cirurgical instruments, weapons, and much more.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p11683a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="428" HEIGHT="236" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p11683a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
The image above shows a diagram of an equipment to sculpt, with a laser, a block of some solid material. In the figure we can see a laser emitter that moves horizontally to the right and left with a constant speed. When the emitter is turned on when moving, a layer a specific width is removed from the block, being vaporized by the laser. 

<P>
The image below illustrates the process of sculpting with a laser, showing an example of (a) a block, with a height of 5 mm and a length of 8 mm, at the start of the process, (b) the format that we want the sculpted block to be, and (c) the sequence of layer removals during the process, considering that in each step, a layer with 1 mm of width is removed. In the first step, the piece numbered 1 is removed; in the second, the one numbered with 2; and so it goes on. During the process of sculpting, the laser was turned on 7 times, in total, once for each removed piece of the block.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">

<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p11683b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="778" HEIGHT="187" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p11683b.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Write a program that, given the height and the length of the block, and its final format, find out the total number of times the laser must be turned on.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains several test cases. Each test case is composed by two lines. The first line of a test case contains two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>A</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>C</I></SPAN>, separated by a blank space, indicating, respectively,
the height (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  A \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>A</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN>) and the length (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le  C \le  10^4$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>C</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">10<SUP>4</SUP></SPAN>) of the block to be sculpted, in milimeters. The second line contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>C</I></SPAN> integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>X</I><SUB>i</SUB></SPAN>, each one indicating the final height, in milimeters of the block between the positions <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I></SPAN> and 
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I> + 1</SPAN> through the length (<!-- MATH
 $0 \le  X_i \le  A$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>X</I><SUB>i</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>A</I></SPAN>, for <!-- MATH
 $0 \le  i \le  C - 1$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>i</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="31" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/116/p11683a.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>C</I> - 1</SPAN>). Consider that on each step, a layer of width 1 mm is removed on the parts of the block where the laser is turned on. 

<P>
The end of the input is indicated by a line that contains only two zeros, separated by a blank space.

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each test case, your program must print a single line, containing an integer, indicating the number of times that the laser must be turned on to sculpt the block in the indicated format. 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
5 8
1 2 3 2 0 3 4 5
3 3
1 0 2
4 3
4 4 1
0
</PRE> 

<P>

<H2><FONT size=4 COLOR=#ff0000><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
7
3
3
</PRE> 

<P>
<BR><HR>

</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>
