<body bgcolor=white lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:35.45pt;line-break:strict'>

<div class=Section1>

<h1 align=center style='text-align:center'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span><![endif]>How Dark Can It Be?</h1>

<p class=MsoBodyText2><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype id="_x0000_t75"
 coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t" path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe"
 filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_s1026" type="#_x0000_t75" style='position:absolute;
 left:0;text-align:left;margin-left:0;margin-top:13.65pt;width:222.35pt;
 height:2in;z-index:1;mso-wrap-distance-left:0;mso-wrap-distance-right:0;
 mso-position-horizontal:left' filled="t">
 <v:fill color2="black"/>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/./p11740_files/image001.png"  o:title=" />
 <v:textbox inset="0,0,0,0"/>
 <w:wrap type="square" side="largest"/>
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=297 height=192
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/./p11740_files/image001.png"  align=left v:shapes="_x0000_s1026"><![endif]>Little
Dipto is fascinated by shadows. He spends hours holding up various objects in
front of the wall, watching the shadow grow and shrink as he moves the object.
But these days he has been developing a special interest in shadows of polygons;
convex polygons to be precise. But he cannot seem to be able to predict the
size of the shadow before he actually cuts out a paper polygon and forms a
shadow of it on the wall. He has now turned to you for help.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;
tab-stops:35.45pt'>Input</h2>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'>The input consists of at most
60 test cases. Each test case starts with an integer N, the number of vertices
in the polygon given. The value of N satisfies 3&lt;=N&lt;=10000. The next N
lines contain a pair of integers each, x and y, specifying the coordinates of
each vertex of the polygon in counterclockwise order (the z-coordinate of each
vertex is always 0). These coordinate values will always be between -10000 and
10000 inclusive. The last line consists of two real numbers 0&lt;=R&lt;=100 and
1&lt;=D&lt;=1000. These two numbers specify the light source: it is a flat
circular source of uniform intensity along the plane z = D, centred on (0,0,D)
and radius R. The wall is a flat, smooth and infinitely large surface along the
plane of z = -D. You may assume that there is no other light source in the vicinity.
You may also assume that the input data will always be such that it specifies a
polygon of non-zero area and that the same point will not be present in the
data multiple times.</p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'>The last input is followed by a
single 0 on the line, which should not be processed.</p>

<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;
tab-stops:35.45pt'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;
tab-stops:35.45pt'>Output</h2>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'>There should be one single line
of output for each test case. It should be formatted as Case c: u t, where c
is the case number with the first case designated as case 1, <i>u</i> is the
area of the umbra (the part of the shadow that is completely dark, usually near
the center) and <i>t</i> is the total area of the shadow, including the lighter
part of the shadow that is only partially dark. The diagram above should help
clarify the terms. Both areas should be within a relative or absolute error bound
of 1e-8 of the actual value. See the sample output below for further
clarification.</p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style='margin-left:2.75pt;
 border-collapse:collapse;mso-padding-alt:2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt'>
 <tr>
  <td width=332 valign=top style='width:249.3pt;border:solid black .1pt;
  border-right:none;padding:2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt'>
  <h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;tab-stops:35.45pt'><span
  style='font-family:Arial;font-weight:normal;font-style:normal'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h2>
  </td>
  <td width=332 valign=top style='width:249.3pt;border:solid black .1pt;
  padding:2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt'>
  <h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;tab-stops:35.45pt'><span
  style='font-family:Arial;font-weight:normal;font-style:normal'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></h2>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width=332 valign=top style='width:249.3pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  solid black .1pt;border-bottom:solid black .1pt;border-right:none;padding:
  2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt'>
  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:
  11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>5<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:
  11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 0<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:
  11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>10 0<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:
  11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>10 10<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:
  11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>1 10<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:
  11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 9<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:

  <p class=TableContents style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:

  </td>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype
 id="_x0000_t75" coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t"
 path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe" filled="f" stroked="f">
 <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
 <v:formulas>
  <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
  <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
  <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
 </v:formulas>
 <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
 <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
</v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_s1060" type="#_x0000_t75" alt="  style='position:absolute;
 left:0;text-align:left;margin-left:0;margin-top:1.6pt;width:121.25pt;height:85.5pt;
 z-index:1;mso-position-horizontal:left'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/i_files/image018.jpg"  o:href="http://www.apartmenttherapy.com/uimages/ny/8-1-tile-question-2.jpg"/>
 <w:wrap type="square"/>
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=162 height=114
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/i_files/image018.jpg"  align=left hspace=12 v:shapes="_x0000_s1060"><![endif]><span
style='font-size:12.0pt'>Today is Tilliby's 9<sup>th</sup> birthday. He has been
receiving all kinds of gifts from people like glow-in-the-dark stickers,
electronic calculator, a new toothbrush and so forth. However, this funny
looking puzzle involving domino tiles caught his attention. The rules were as
follows  the puzzle consisted of a rectangular grid of R-by-C cells, and it
must be completely filled by 2x1 sized tiles, of which there is sufficient
supply. No two tiles may overlap. To complicate things even more, certain cells
of the grid is marked unusable, which must not be covered by any of the tiles.
All other cells, however, must be covered by exactly one tile. Now in spite of
all these complications, this was an easy exercise for Tilliby. However, when
it came to counting the number of ways this can be solved, even his new and
shiny calculator could not help him. Can you? <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 align=left style='margin-top:12.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:left;mso-pagination:none;mso-hyphenate:none;
tab-stops:173.25pt'><span style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Garamond'>Input<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                     </span><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>The
input consists of at most 100 test cases. Each test case starts with a line
containing 3 integers, <b>R</b>, <b>C</b> and <b>N</b>. This line will be
followed by <b>N</b> other lines, each containing two integers, <b>r<sub>i</sub></b>
and <b>c<sub>i</sub></b>, where <b>r<sub>i</sub></b> is the row position of the
<b>i<sup>th</sup></b> unusable cell and <b>c<sub>i</sub></b> is the column
position. All these input integers will be within the following ranges: 1 &lt;=
<b>R </b>&lt;= 4, 1 &lt;= <b>C </b>&lt;= 100000000, 0 &lt;= <b>N </b>&lt;= 100,
0 &lt;= <b>r<sub>i </sub></b>&lt; <b>R</b>, 0 &lt;= <b>c<sub>i </sub></b>&lt; <b>C</b>.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>The
last test case will be followed by a single line containing three 0 (zeroes)
which should not be processed.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 align=left style='margin-top:12.0pt;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:6.0pt;
margin-left:0in;text-align:left;mso-pagination:none;mso-hyphenate:none'><span
style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Garamond'>Output<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>The
output for each test case should consist of one single line of the form Case
c: x, where c is the serial number of the test case starting from 1, and x is
the number of ways the specified tiling can be performed. Since this number can
be very large, output its value in mod 10000007.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0

11742||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem A: Social Constraints</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem A: Social Constraints</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11742.jpg"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Socializing can be a very complicated thing among teenagers. For
example, finding a good seating arrangement in a movie theater can be a
difficult task. Here is a list of constraints that could potentially
apply to two individuals A and B in this situation:
</p><ul><li>if A and B are dating, then they must sit beside each other
</li><li>if A and B are fighting, then they cannot sit beside each other
</li><li>if A and B have just broke up, then they must sit at opposite ends of the row
</li></ul>
<p>Teenage politics is a complicated thing meaning the constraints can
get even more complicated than those listed above.
However, we restrict this problem to a particular form of constraint
that simply specifies a lower or upper bound on the number of seats
separating two specific individuals.
</p>
<p>The group arrives after everyone else watching the show has been
seated. By some stroke of luck, there are exactly as many open seats as
there are teenagers and all of these seats appear consecutively in the
front row. How many possible seating arrangements satisfy the
constraints?
</p>

<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>Each test case begins with two integers n and m with 0 &lt; n â¤ 8
and 0 â¤ m â¤ 20
where n is the size of the group. For simplicity, assume the teenagers
are numbered from 0 to n-1. Then of m lines follow, each describing a
constraint, where a line consists of three integers a,b,c satisfying 0
â¤ a &lt; b &lt; n and 0 &lt; |c| &lt; n. If c is positive then
teenagers a and b must sit at most c seats apart. If
c is negative, then a and b must sit at least -c seats apart. The end
of input is signaled by a line consisting of n = m = 0.
</p>

<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>The output for each test case is a single line containing the number
of possible seating arrangements for the group that satisfy all of the
social constraints.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>3 1
0 1 -2
3 0
0 0
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>2
6
</pre>

<hr>
<em>Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11743||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem B: Credit Check</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem B: Credit Check</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11743.jpg"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>These days, it has become commonplace to make purchases over the
internet using a credit card. However, because credit card numbers are
relatively long, it is easy to make a mistake while typing them in. In
order to quickly identify errors like typos, most e-commerce websites
use a checksum algorithm to verify credit card numbers.</p>
<p>One popular checksum algorithm is the Luhn algorithm, which can
detect any single-digit error as well as many common multiple-digit
errors:</p>

<ol>
<li>Starting with the second-last digit and moving backwards, double every other digit to obtain a list of numbers.</li>
<li>Add up the digits of these numbers, then add the undoubled digits from the original number.  Sum the two results.</li>
<li>If the total ends in a 0, the credit card number is valid, and it is invalid otherwise.</li>
</ol>
<p>For example, using the number 5181 2710 9900 0012:</p>
<ol>
<li>Double the appropriate digits (<strong>5</strong>1<strong>8</strong>1 <strong>2</strong>7<strong>1</strong>0 <strong>9</strong>9<strong>0</strong>0 <strong>0</strong>0<strong>1</strong>2) to obtain the values: 10, 16, 4, 2, 18, 0, 0, 2.</li>
<li>Add up the digits of these values to get (1+0) + (1+6) + 4 + 2 +
(1+8) + 0 + 0 + 2 = 25. The sum of the undoubled digits is
1+1+7+0+9+0+0+2 = 20, so the total is 20+25=45.</li>
<li>45 does not end in a 0, so this credit card number is invalid.</li>
</ol>

<p>For this problem, you must write a program that checks the validity of credit card numbers according to the Luhn algorithm.</p>

<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>The input begins with a number <em>N</em> on a single line, followed by <em>N</em> lines each containing a single credit card number.
Each credit card number consists of 16 decimal digits in groups of four separated by single spaces.</p>

<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>The output consists of one line for each input credit card number.
If the credit card number is valid, this line consists of the string
"Valid", otherwise it reads "Invalid".</p>

<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>2
5181 2710 9900 0012
5181 2710 9900 0017
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>Invalid
Valid
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Sumudu Fernando</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11744||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem C: Parallel Carry Adder</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem C: Parallel Carry Adder</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11744.jpg"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Let a and b be two 31-bit binary numbers.  Consider the following method for computing a+b.  Let c,d be 31-bit numbers
such that:
</p><ul><li>c<sub>i</sub> = 1 if a<sub>i</sub> â  b<sub>i</sub>
</li><li>c<sub>i</sub> = 0 if a<sub>i</sub> = b<sub>i</sub>
</li><li>d<sub>i</sub> = 1 if a<sub>i</sub> = b<sub>i</sub> = 1
</li><li>d<sub>i</sub> = 0 if a<sub>i</sub> = 0 or b<sub>i</sub> = 0
</li></ul><p>Now, replace a with c and b with 2*d and repeat these steps until either b = 0
or b â¥ 2<sup>31</sup>.  In the former case, the resulting value of a is the sum
of the original numbers.  In the latter case, the sum of the original numbers
requires 32 bits to express so we say that an overflow has occurred.
</p>
<p>Your task is to print the results of all intermediate calculations and report if an overflow occurs.
</p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>The first number indicates the number of test cases.  Each test case consists of two 31-bit numbers
a and b.
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>The output for each test case is a series of lines. The first line
consists of a and b written in binary and separated by a space.
Following this, each line consists of the resulting values of a and b
when one iteration of the algorithm is applied to the values
in the previous line. Again, these should be written in binary and
separated by a space. If any of these numbers has value at
least 2<sup>31</sup> then the message "overflow" should be printed in place of the number.  The last line of output to
be printed corresponds to the iteration when either b = 0 or b â¥ 2<sup>31</sup>.  The output for consecutive
input cases should be separated by a blank line.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>2
0000000000010000000101011101011 1000010110000110000000111111111
1100000000000000000000000000000 0100000000000000000000000000000
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>0000000000010000000101011101011 1000010110000110000000111111111
1000010110010110000101100010100 0000000000000000000000111010110
1000010110010110000101011000010 0000000000000000000001000101000
1000010110010110000100011101010 0000000000000000000010000000000
1000010110010110000110011101010 0000000000000000000000000000000

1100000000000000000000000000000 0100000000000000000000000000000
1000000000000000000000000000000 1000000000000000000000000000000
0000000000000000000000000000000 overflow
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

11745||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem D: Slitherlink</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem D: Slitherlink</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11745.png"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>The puzzle game Slitherlink is played on a grid.  Each cell of the grid contains either a space or an integer from 0 to 3.
The goal is to draw in some grid lines connecting vertically or horizonally adjacent points on the grid
subject to the following constraints:
</p><ol><li>If a grid cell is numbered k then exactly k out of the 4 adjacent grid lines are drawn.
</li><li>The grid lines form a single loop that does not cross itself.
</li></ol><p>Determining if a given instance of a Slitherlink puzzle
can be completed or not is NP-complete which means nobody knows of an
efficient algorithm to solve the problem for large grids. Your task is
simpler. Given an instance of a Slitherlink puzzle and a proposed
solution, you are to check that the solution indeed satisfies the
constraints for that puzzle.
</p>
<p>For example, the first sample input is not valid since there are 2 grid lines drawn adjacent to a cell numbered 1.
The second, third, and fourth samples are invalid since the grid lines do not form a single loop.
However, the fifth sample is valid.
</p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>The first integer denotes the number of test cases to follow.  Each test case is specified by a 
line containing two positive integers R and C (both at most 50) followed by a grid of 2R+1 rows of 2C+1 characters.
The contents of row r and column c (counting from 1) are as follows:
</p><ol><li>if both r and c are odd then the character is a '+' indicating a grid point
</li><li>if both r and c are even then the character is either a space
or one of 0, 1, 2, or 3 indicating the contents of the corresponding
grid space
</li><li>if r is odd and c is even then the character is either a space or - indicating a drawn horizontal grid line
</li><li>if r is even and c is odd then the character is either a space or | indicating a drawn vertical grid line
</li></ol><p>You can assume all inputs are well-formed descriptions of a Slitherlink puzzle and a proposed solution.
A blank line also precedes each test case.
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>The output for each test case is a single line containing either <code>Valid</code> or <code>Invalid</code>, depending on whether the proposed
solution is valid or not.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>5

3 3
+ +-+ +
 1| |2 
+-+ +-+
|  1  |
+-+-+ +
 1  |3|
+ + +-+

2 3
+-+ +-+
|3| |3|
+ + + +
|3| |3|
+-+ +-+

2 2
+-+-+
|3|3|
+ + +
|3|3|
+-+-+

2 2
+ +-+
 2| |
+-+-+
| |2 
+-+ +

3 4
+ +-+-+ +
  |   |2 
+-+ + +-+
|3 0   3|
+-+ +-+-+
  | |  1 
+ +-+ + +
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>Invalid
Invalid
Invalid
Invalid
Valid
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

11746||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem E: Finding the Transmitter Again</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem E: Finding the Transmitter Again</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11746.jpg"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>SOS! Your boss has misplaced an important (and expensive) radio
transmitter somewhere in a large, rectangular cornpatch. He refuses to
explain why he took the transmitter out into the cornpatch, but he has
tasked you with finding it. Thankfully, he has already set up three
radio receivers in the cornpatch to help you narrow down the possible
locations to search.
</p>
<p>The receivers are designed in such a way that they can only measure
the signal strength at their location, and not which direction it is
coming from. Furthermore, they are too large to easily move.
</p>
<p>You know that for this particular model of transmitter, the signal strength at a positive distance <em>d</em> is given by the expression <em>P/d<sup>2</sup></em>, where <em>P</em>
is the power level of the transmitter. Unfortunately, you don't know
what power level the transmitter is currently set to, only that it is
positive.
</p>
<p>Write a program that reads as input the locations and readings of
the receivers, and outputs a list of possible locations of the
transmitter.
</p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>The input begins with a number <em>N</em> on a single line, followed by <em>N</em> testcases.
</p>
<p>Each testcase consists of three lines, each containing the location (as two integers <em>x<sub>i</sub></em> <em>y<sub>i</sub></em>) and power reading (as an integer <em>p<sub>i</sub></em>) from one of the receivers.  You are assured that 0 â¤ <em>x<sub>i</sub></em>, <em>y<sub>i</sub></em> â¤ 1,000, 0 &lt; <em>p<sub>i</sub></em> â¤ 100,000, and that the receivers are located at three distinct points.
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>For each testcase, output one line containing first the number of
possible locations of the transmitter, followed by the possible
locations themselves (in the form <em>x<sub>t</sub></em> <em>y<sub>t</sub></em>).  A location is possible if it is within the cornpatch (0 â¤ <em>x<sub>t</sub></em>, <em>y<sub>t</sub></em> â¤ 1,000), and a transmitter there could produce the given receiver readings for some positive power level <em>P</em>.
</p>
<p>The output coordinates should be rounded to exactly two decimal
places, and multiple output locations should be sorted by increasing
x-coordinate, breaking ties by increasing y-coordinate. You are
guaranteed that the input data will determine a finite, non-zero number
of possible locations. Furthermore, the input will be such that a small
perturbation (on the order of 10<sup>-6</sup>) in the receiver positions would not change the number of possible locations.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>2
100 0 50
100 100 50
0 100 50
100 0 50
100 100 50
0 100 25
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>1 50.00 50.00
2 67.71 50.00 332.29 50.00
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Sumudu Fernando</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11747||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem F: Heavy Cycle Edges</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem F: Heavy Cycle Edges</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11747.png"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Given an undirected graph with edge weights, a minimum spanning tree is a subset of edges of
minimum total weight such that any two nodes are connected by some path containing only these edges.
A popular algorithm for finding the minimum spanning tree T in a graph proceeds as follows:
</p><ul><li>let T be initially empty
</li><li>consider the edges e<sub>1</sub>, ..., e<sub>m</sub> in increasing order of weight
<ul><li>add e<sub>i</sub> to T if the endpoints of e<sub>i</sub> are not connected by a path in T
</li></ul></li></ul><p>An alternative algorithm is the following:
</p><ul><li>let T be initially the set of all edges
</li><li>while there is some cycle C in T
<ul><li>remove edge e from T where e has the heaviest weight in C
</li></ul></li></ul><p>Your task is to implement a function related to this algorithm.  Given an undirected graph G with edge weights,
your task is to output all edges that are the heaviest edge in some cycle of G.
</p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>The first input of each case begins with integers n and m with 1 â¤ n â¤ 1,000 and 0 â¤ m â¤ 25,000
where n is the number of nodes and m is the number of edges in the graph.
Following this are m lines containing three integers u, v, and w describing a weight w edge connecting nodes u and v
where 0 â¤ u, v &lt; n and 0 â¤ w &lt; 2<sup>31</sup>.  Input is 
terminated with a line containing n = m = 0; this case
should not be processed.  You may assume no two edges have the same weight and no two nodes are directly
connected by more than one edge.
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>Output for an input case consists of a single line containing the weights of all edges that are the heaviest edge
in some cycle of the input graph.  These weights should appear in increasing order and consecutive weights should
be separated by a space.  If there are no cycles in the graph then output the text <code>forest</code> instead of numbers.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>3 3
0 1 1
1 2 2
2 0 3
4 5
0 1 1
1 2 2
2 3 3
3 1 4
0 2 0
3 1
0 1 1
0 0
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>3
2 4
forest
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11748||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem G: Rigging Elections</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem G: Rigging Elections</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11748.jpg"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Elections in your country are performed in a one-on-one elimination style.  Each week, two
people are chosen from a pool of candidates and the country votes on which one they prefer.
The loser is eliminated and the winner is returned to the pool of candidates. 
This process continues until only one candidate remains.
</p>
<p>To make a bad voting system even worse, a single person is charged with the responsibility
of choosing the two candidates each week.  This person happens to be you!  Since you are a very
selfish person, you plan on rigging the election so your preferred candidate wins.  You have
access to polling data from which you can determine who would win in every possible head-to-head matchup.
Assuming the data accurately represents what the real outcome would be,
is it possible to schedule the candidates so your candidate wins?
</p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>The first line of each test case contains three integers n, m, and c
with 1 â¤ n â¤ 100, 1 â¤ m â¤ 100 and 1 â¤ c â¤ n.
Here, n indicates the total number of candidates in the initial pool, m
is the number of voters and c is the number of your preferred
candidate.
This is followed by m lines, each containing a permutation of the
numbers 1 through n. The i'th line should be interpreted
as a ranking of the n candidates by voter i. If two candidates are
pitted against each other in an election, then voter i will vote for
whoever
appears first in their list. You may also assume m is always odd. The
last line of input contains three zeros and should not be processed.
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>There is a single line of output for each test case with either the message <code>yes</code> or <code>no</code> indicating if it is possible
for you to rig the elections so your preferred candidate c wins.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>3 3 1
1 2 3
2 3 1
3 1 2
3 3 1
1 2 3
2 3 1
3 2 1
0 0 0
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>yes
no
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Zac Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11749||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem H: Poor Trade Advisor</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem H: Poor Trade Advisor</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11749.jpg"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Yesterday, you were working on a strange machine found in an old garage (later, you find out it was <em>Dr. Emmett Brown</em>'s
garage), when you accidentally pushed a button and were sent back in
time to 48 BC with only a laptop in your hand! Fortunately, you knew
enough Latin to communicate with one of the locals who turned out to be
Caesar's trade advisor. The advisor invited you to his house and gave
you food. In return, you asked him how you could help him. He answered
that recently, Caesar has decided to establish a new province in a high
profit region of his empire. The empire is a network of cities
connected by bidirectional roads, and each road has a certain <em>profit per annum</em> (PPA) value.  The PPA of any given road is calculated by subtracting its annual upkeep cost from its annual revenue.
</p>
<p>The new province will consist of a connected, non-empty set of roads
(and the corresponding cities). The province must also have the highest
possible average PPA. Caesar further asked his trade advisor to
determine the maximum possible number of cities in such a province.
Now, the advisor needs your help to solve this problem, or he is
worried that Caesar will put him to the sword. You decide to write a
program to solve this problem, but you should remember that your laptop
has a limited remaining battery and you must be fast!
</p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>Each test case starts with two integers 1 &lt; <em>n</em> â¤ 500 and 1 â¤ <em>m</em> â¤ 1,000,000, the numbers of cities and roads in the empire respectively. The next <em>m</em> lines each contain three integers where the first two are distinct, between 1 and <em>n</em>,
and represent the endpoints of a road, while the third integer is the
PPA of that road (fits in a signed 32 bit variable). Input is
terminated with a line consisting of <em>n</em> = <em>m</em> = 0.
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>There is one line of output for each test case consisting of a single 
integer that is the maximum number of cities in a highest average PPA 
province.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>4 5
1 2 100
1 3 100
1 4 1
2 3 100
3 4 1
9 14
1 2 9
6 9 8
2 4 9
2 3 9
4 5 1
4 3 9
5 9 2
9 8 9
7 8 9
7 9 5
6 7 9
5 6 4
5 8 7
7 5 9
0 0
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>3
5
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Babak Behsaz</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11750||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem I: Red-Blue Tree</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem I: Red-Blue Tree</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11750.jpg"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>Given a rooted tree T and a set S of pairs of vertices from T, we
say that T is a red-blue tree on S if it is possible to colour every
vertex in the tree with either red or blue such that the following
holds:
</p>
<p>For each pair of vertices (a,b) in S, consider the unique path in T
connecting a to b. Any two vertices on this path that share a common
parent in T
must be coloured with different colours.
</p>
<p>Given a rooted tree T, a set of vertex pairs S, and the fact that T
is a red-blue tree on S, you are to find the maximum number of pairs
from S that can be simultaneously connected in T using each tree edge
at most once.
</p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>Each test case starts with three integers 1 â¤ <em>n</em> â¤ 100, 0 â¤ <em>k</em> â¤ 3000 and 1 â¤ r â¤ n which are the number of vertices, number of pairs and index of the root, respectively. Next <em>n</em> -1 lines contain two integers between 1 and <em>n</em> describing two endpoints of an edge. Next <em>k</em> lines contain two integers between 1 and <em>n</em> giving a pair of vertices. Input is terminated with a line consisting of <em>n</em> = <em>k</em> = <em>r</em> = 0. You are guaranteed each input graph is a connected
tree rooted at the given <em>r</em> and is a red-blue tree on the given pairs.
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>There is a line of output for each test case containing the maximum
number of pairs from the given list that can be simultaneously
connected using each tree edge at most once.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>16 12 1
1 2
1 3
1 4
1 5
1 6
1 7
2 8
2 9
2 10
3 11
3 12
3 13
4 14
4 15
4 16
8 5
5 9
6 8
6 12
7 11
7 15
8 10
9 10
11 13
12 13
14 16
15 16
0 0 0
</pre>
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>6
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Babak Behsaz</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________
11751||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><head>


	<title>Problem J: Installing Diagnostic Software</title>
	<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
</head><body>

<h2>Problem J: Installing Diagnostic Software</h2>

<font color="white"><img src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/p11751.gif"  width="400" align="right" border="5"></font>
<p>You have recently been appointed as the administrator for a wired
network of devices. Unfortunately, your predecessor used very poor
quality lines to connect the devices. The board of executives is
currently deciding if they want to fund an upgrade to a wireless
network, or simply replace the existing wires with ones of better
quality. As expected, this decision is being weighed down with
bureaucratic nonsense; it looks like it will take some time before
anything is approved.
</p>
<p>Meanwhile, you still have to deal with the problem at hand. You have
access to an antiquated version of Newton Network Monitor which is a
software package that, once installed on a machine, will monitor all
lines connected to that machine and immediately alert the user when a
line has failed. This should help reduce your response time to any
failures.
</p>
<p>Your task is to install the software on some machines so each line
is being monitored by at least one of its endpoint devices. For various
technical reasons, the time it takes to install the software varies
from device to device so you want to minimize the total amount of time
spent installing the software. You cannot install on more than one
machine at a time (since you only have one copy of the software)
meaning the total time spent installing the software is exactly the sum
of the installation times on each machine. </p>
<h3>Input Format</h3>
<p>Each input case begins with two numbers n,m with 1 â¤ n â¤ 1,000 and 0
â¤ m â¤ 25,000. Following this are m pairs of distinct integers between 0
and n-1 which describe a wire connecting the two devices. The time
spent installing the software on machine numbered i is 2<sup>i</sup>.  The input is terminated with n = m = 0; this should not be processed. 
</p>
<h3>Output Format</h3>
<p>For each input case, there is to be one line of output containing a
sequence of n bits with no spaces. The i'th bit is 1 if the software is
installed on machine i, and 0 if not.
</p>
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>3 2
0 2
1 2
3 1
1 2
0 0
</pre>
<h2>Sample Output</h2>
<pre>110
010
</pre>
<hr>
<em>Zachary Friggstad</em>

</body></html>

______________________________________________________

   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 3"/>
  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"
   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 3"/>
  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"
   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 3"/>
  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"
   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 3"/>
  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"
   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 3"/>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:36.0pt'>

<div class=Section1>

<div align=center>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:1184;mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid black;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid black'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes;
  height:55.7pt'>
  <td width=111 style='width:83.4pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid black .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:48.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>A</span></b><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
  14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=463 style='width:347.25pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;border-left:
  none;mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>The
  Super Powers</span></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=81 style='width:60.4pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;border-left:none;
  mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype id="_x0000_t75"
   coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t" path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe"
   filled="f" stroked="f">
   <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
   <v:formulas>
    <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>

  src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/a_files/image001.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1026"><![endif]><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

   </o:OLEObject>
  </xml><![endif]--><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>We all know the Super Powers of
this world and how they manage to get advantages in political warfare or even
in other sectors. But this is not a political platform and so we will talk
about a different kind of super powers  The Super Power Numbers. A positive
number is said to be super power when it is the power of at least two different
positive integers. For example 64 is a super power as 64 = 8<sup>2</sup> and 64
<span class=GramE>=<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>4<sup>3</sup></span>.
You have to write a program that lists all super powers within 1 and 2<sup>64</sup>
-1 (inclusive).<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>   </span></p>

<p class=MsoHeading7 style='line-height:115%'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span
style='font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;line-height:115%'>Input<br>
</span></span><span class=GramE><span style='font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;
font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"'>This</span></span><span style='font-size:
11.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Calibri","sans-serif"'> program has no
input.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h4><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></span></h4>

<h4 style='line-height:115%'><span class=StyleArial16pt><span style='font-size:
14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;line-height:115%'>Output <o:p></o:p></span></span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:143.25pt'>Print all the
Super Power Numbers within 1 and 2^64 -1. Each line contains a single super
power number and the numbers are printed in ascending order.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span></p>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:1184;mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid black;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid black'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>
  <td width=327 valign=top style='width:245.5pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <h1 align=left style='text-align:left'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;
  mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";font-style:normal'>Sample
  Input<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>       </span><span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                       </span><o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>
  </td>
  <td width=327 valign=top style='width:245.55pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <h1 align=left style='text-align:left'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;
  mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";font-style:normal'>Partial
  Judge Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></h1>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=327 valign=top style='width:245.5pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;

</table>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>You are
helping the problem setters of International Creating Palindrome <span
class=GramE>Contest(</span>ICPC) in problem setting for the upcoming contest.
In ICPC contestants are given some problems. Each problem is an integer
sequence. The goal of the contestants is to convert the sequence into a
palindromic integer sequence. A palindromic integer sequence is an integer
sequence that is the same sequence when written from forwards or backwards,
i.e., of the form {a1, a2, a3, 
<span class=GramE>. ,</span> a3, a2, a1}. Some
examples of palindromic sequences are {78, 91, 78}, {100}, {10, 20, 20, 10}, {5,
5} etc. But {1, 2, 3, 1}, {10, 20} are not palindromic sequence. You can
convert {1, 2, 3, 1} to a palindromic sequence by inserting a 2 at 4<sup>th</sup>
position which will become {1, 2, 3, 2, 1} and you can convert {10, 20} to
palindromic sequence by inserting 20 at first or inserting 10 at last.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>As contestant
will be given <span class=GramE>problems(</span>Integer sequences) with
different difficulties, problem setters are asked to create problems of
different difficulties. The difficulty of a problem is represented by an
integer, for example, 0, 1, 2, 3<span class=GramE>,...</span> etc. The
difficulty of a problem is D, if at least D insertions of integer required <span
class=GramE>to convert</span> the given sequence into palindromic sequence.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>Problem
setters are also asked to give problems with difficulty not greater than K.
Your job is to determine the difficulty of a given sequence to help the problem
setters. If the given sequence is already a palindrome, it cannot be used in
the contest. So you have to answer Too easy without quotes. If the difficulty
of the given sequence is more than K, that problem also cannot be used. In that
case you have to answer Too difficult without quotes. Otherwise you just have
to answer the difficulty.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:16.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Input</span></b><b><span
style='font-size:16.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><br>
</span></b>Input will start with an integer <span class=GramE>T(</span>1&lt;=T&lt;=100),
number of test cases. Each test case starts with two integers <span
class=GramE>N(</span>1&lt;=N&lt;=10000) and K(0&lt;=K&lt;=20), the length of
integer sequence and maximum allowed difficulty.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Output</span></b><b><span
style='font-size:16.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><br>
</span></b>For each test case, output a single line of the form Case X: D.
Here X is the case number. If the given sequence is already a palindromic
sequence D will be Too easy without quotes, if the difficulty of the given
sequence is greater than K D will be Too difficult, <span class=SpellE>other
wise</span> D will be the difficulty of the given sequence. See the sample
input and output for exact format.</p>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=665

  <w:IgnoreMixedContent>false</w:IgnoreMixedContent>
  <w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>false</w:AlwaysShowPlaceholderText>
  <w:DoNotPromoteQF/>
  <w:LidThemeOther>EN-US</w:LidThemeOther>
  <w:LidThemeAsian>X-NONE</w:LidThemeAsian>
  <w:LidThemeComplexScript>BN-BD</w:LidThemeComplexScript>
  <w:Compatibility>
   <w:BreakWrappedTables/>
   <w:SnapToGridInCell/>
   <w:WrapTextWithPunct/>
   <w:UseAsianBreakRules/>
   <w:DontGrowAutofit/>
   <w:DontUseIndentAsNumberingTabStop/>
   <w:FELineBreak11/>
   <w:WW11IndentRules/>
   <w:DontAutofitConstrainedTables/>
   <w:AutofitLikeWW11/>
   <w:HangulWidthLikeWW11/>
   <w:UseNormalStyleForList/>
  </w:Compatibility>
  <w:BrowserLevel>MicrosoftInternetExplorer4</w:BrowserLevel>
  <m:mathPr>
   <m:mathFont m:val="Cambria Math"/>
   <m:brkBin m:val="before"/>
   <m:brkBinSub m:val="--"/>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:36.0pt'>

<div class=Section1>

<div align=center>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:1184;mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid black;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid black'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes;
  height:55.7pt'>
  <td width=106 style='width:79.65pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid black .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:48.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>C</span></b><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
  14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=437 style='width:327.9pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;border-left:none;
  mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:36.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Code
  Feat</span></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:
  28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=111 style='width:83.5pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;border-left:none;
  mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype id="_x0000_t75"
   coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t" path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe"
   filled="f" stroked="f">
   <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
   <v:formulas>
    <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
   </v:formulas>
   <v:path o:extrusionok="f" gradientshapeok="t" o:connecttype="rect"/>
   <o:lock v:ext="edit" aspectratio="t"/>
  </v:shapetype><v:shape id="_x0000_i1025" type="#_x0000_t75" style='width:81pt;
   height:79.5pt' o:ole=" >
   <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/c_files/image001.png"  o:title=" />
  </v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=108 height=106
  src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/c_files/image001.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
   <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="PBrush" ShapeID="_x0000_i1025"
    DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1324936627">
   </o:OLEObject>
  </xml><![endif]--><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>Hooray!<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Agent Bauer has shot the terrorists, blown up
the bad guy base, saved the hostages, exposed the moles in the government,
prevented an environmental catastrophe, and found homes for three orphaned
kittens, all in the span of 19 consecutive hours.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>But now, he only has 5 hours remaining to
deal with his final challenge: an activated nuclear bomb protected by a
security code.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Can you help him figure
out the code and deactivate it?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Events
occur in real time.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>The government
hackers at CTU (Counter-Terrorist Unit) have learned some things about the
code, but they still haven't quite solved it.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>
</span>They know it's a single, strictly positive, integer.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>They also know several clues of the form &quot;when
divided by X, the remainder is one of {Y1, Y2, Y3<span class=GramE>, ...,</span>
<span class=SpellE>Yk</span>}&quot;.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>
</span>There are multiple solutions to these clues, but the code is likely to
be one of the smallest ones.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>So they'd
like you to print out the first few solutions, in increasing order.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>The world is
counting on you!</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>Input consists
of several test cases.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Each test case
starts with a line containing C, the number of clues (1 &lt;= C &lt;= 9), and
S, the number of desired solutions (1 &lt;= S &lt;= 10).<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>The next C lines each start with two integers
X (2 &lt;= X) and k (1 &lt;= k &lt;= 100), followed by the k distinct integers
Y1, Y2<span class=GramE>, ...,</span> <span class=SpellE>Yk</span> (0 &lt;= Y1,
Y2, ..., <span class=SpellE>Yk</span> &lt; X).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>You may assume
that the Xs in each test case are <span class=SpellE>pairwise</span> relatively
prime (<span class=SpellE>ie</span>, they have no common factor except 1).<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Also, the product of the Xs will fit into a
32-bit integer.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>The last test
case is followed by a line containing two zeros.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>For each test
case, output S lines containing the S smallest positive solutions to the clues,
in increasing order.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'>Print a blank
line after the output for each test case.</p>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=665
 style='width:498.8pt;margin-left:2.75pt;border-collapse:collapse;mso-padding-alt:
 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;height:16.1pt'>
  <td width=332 valign=top style='width:249.3pt;border-top:solid black 1.0pt;
  border-left:solid black 1.0pt;border-bottom:none black 1.0pt;border-right:
  none;mso-border-top-alt:solid black .25pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid black .25pt;
  mso-border-bottom-alt:none black 0cm;padding:2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt;
  height:16.1pt'>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'><b><span
  style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Sample Input<span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'>            </span><span
  style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                  </span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=333 valign=top style='width:249.5pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;
  border-bottom:none black 1.0pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .25pt;mso-border-bottom-alt:
  none black 0cm;padding:2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt;height:16.1pt'>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'><b><span
  style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <![if !supportMisalignedRows]>
  <td style='height:16.1pt;border:none' width=0 height=21></td>
  <![endif]>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes;height:13.8pt'>
  <td width=332 valign=top style='width:249.3pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  solid black 1.0pt;border-bottom:solid black 1.0pt;border-right:none;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid black .25pt;mso-border-top-alt:solid black .25pt;
  mso-border-left-alt:solid black .25pt;mso-border-bottom-alt:solid black .25pt;
  padding:2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt;height:13.8pt'>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>3 2<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>2 1 <span class=SpellE>1</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>5 2 0 3<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>3 2 1 2<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'><b><span
  style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 <span class=SpellE>0</span><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=333 valign=top style='width:249.5pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid black .25pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .25pt;
  padding:2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt 2.75pt;height:13.8pt'>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'>5</p>
  <p class=TableContents style='layout-grid-mode:char'>13</p>
  </td>
  <![if !supportMisalignedRows]>
  <td style='height:13.8pt;border:none' width=0 height=18></td>
  <![endif]>
 </tr>

mso-border-bottom-alt:solid windowtext .75pt;padding:0cm 0cm 1.0pt 0cm'>

solid windowtext .75pt;padding:0cm;mso-padding-alt:0cm 0cm 1.0pt 0cm'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

	mso-level-tab-stop:none;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	text-indent:-36.0pt;}
@list l1:level5
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5";
	mso-level-tab-stop:none;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:198.0pt;
	text-indent:-54.0pt;}
@list l1:level6
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6";
	mso-level-tab-stop:none;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:234.0pt;
	text-indent:-54.0pt;}
@list l1:level7
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6\.%7";
	mso-level-tab-stop:none;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:288.0pt;
	text-indent:-72.0pt;}
@list l1:level8
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6\.%7\.%8";
	mso-level-tab-stop:none;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:324.0pt;
	text-indent:-72.0pt;}
@list l1:level9
	{mso-level-text:"%1\.%2\.%3\.%4\.%5\.%6\.%7\.%8\.%9";
	mso-level-tab-stop:none;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	margin-left:378.0pt;
	text-indent:-90.0pt;}
ol
	{margin-bottom:0cm;}
ul
	{margin-bottom:0cm;}
-->
</style>
<!--[if gte mso 10]>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:36.0pt'>

<div class=Section1>

<div align=center>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;

 .5pt solid black;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid black'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes;
  height:55.7pt'>
  <td width=106 style='width:79.65pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid black .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:48.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>D</span></b><b
  style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
  14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=437 style='width:327.9pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;border-left:none;
  mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:36.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:24.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Table
  Tennis</span></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=111 style='width:83.5pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;border-left:none;
  mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;height:55.7pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;
  text-align:center;line-height:normal'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype id="_x0000_t75"
   coordsize="21600,21600" o:spt="75" o:preferrelative="t" path="m@4@5l@4@11@9@11@9@5xe"
   filled="f" stroked="f">
   <v:stroke joinstyle="miter"/>
   <v:formulas>
    <v:f eqn="if lineDrawn pixelLineWidth 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @0 1 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum 0 0 @1"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @2 1 2"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelWidth"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @3 21600 pixelHeight"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @0 0 1"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @6 1 2"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelWidth"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @8 21600 0"/>
    <v:f eqn="prod @7 21600 pixelHeight"/>
    <v:f eqn="sum @10 21600 0"/>
   </v:formulas>

   height:79.5pt' o:ole=" >
   <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/d_files/image001.png"  o:title=" />
  </v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=108 height=106
  src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/d_files/image001.png"  v:shapes="_x0000_i1025"><![endif]><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
   <o:OLEObject Type="Embed" ProgID="PBrush" ShapeID="_x0000_i1025"
    DrawAspect="Content" ObjectID="_1324936743">
   </o:OLEObject>
  </xml><![endif]--><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
  style='font-size:28.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman","serif"'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shape
 id="Picture_x0020_1" o:spid="_x0000_s1026" type="#_x0000_t75" alt="http://www.clker.com/cliparts/2/9/c/7/11949867871570711906table_tennis_omar_abo-na_01.svg.hi.png"
 style='position:absolute;left:0;text-align:left;margin-left:0;margin-top:9.2pt;
 width:177.75pt;height:162.75pt;z-index:1;visibility:visible;
 mso-position-horizontal:left'>
 <v:imagedata src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/d_files/image001.png"  o:title="11949867871570711906table_tennis_omar_abo-na_01"/>
 <w:wrap type="square"/>
</v:shape><![endif]--><![if !vml]><img width=237 height=217
src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/117/d_files/image001.png"  align=left hspace=12
alt="http://www.clker.com/cliparts/2/9/c/7/11949867871570711906table_tennis_omar_abo-na_01.svg.hi.png"
v:shapes="Picture_x0020_1"><![endif]><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Table tennis is a two/four player sport
that originated in England. The scoring system of this game has changed with
time. For this problem we will consider the two-player version of the game that
abides by the following scoring rules (note that this rule is significantly
different from the usual ones)  <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='text-align:justify;text-indent:-18.0pt;
line-height:normal;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:
Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Player 1 makes the first move. The players
alternate serve every 5 points. That means serves [1<span class=GramE>,5</span>]
are done by player 1, serves [6, 10] are done by player 2, serves [11, 15] are
done by player 1 and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='text-align:justify;text-indent:-18.0pt;
line-height:normal;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:
Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>In each serve, one of the two players
wins a point. The first player to reach 21 points wins the game.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='text-align:justify;text-indent:-18.0pt;
line-height:normal;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo1'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:
Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>If the scores are 20-20 (deuce), the
scores are reset to 15-15.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Given
a partial game, the probability of player 1 winning a point on his serve and
the probability of player 1 winning a point on the opponents serve, can you
find out the probability of player 1 winning the game?<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;line-height:normal'><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Input<br>
</span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>The
first line of input is an integer <span class=GramE>T(</span>T&lt;1000) that
indicates the number of test cases. Each case consists of two lines. The first
line is a string consisting of the letters W and L only. The length of this
string is non-negative and can have a maximum value of 100. The string gives
the status of the game so far. If the <span class=SpellE><b>i<sup>th</sup></b></span>
character (1 based) is W, that means player 1 won the <span class=SpellE><b>i<sup>th</sup></b></span>
point. Similarly, L indicates that the player 1 lost that point. The next
line consists of two real numbers, <b>P1 P2</b>, in the range [0, 1], with at
most 3 digits after the decimal point. P1 is the probability of player 1
winning a point on his serve and P2 is the probability of player 1 winning a
point on player 2s serve.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Output<br>
</span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>For each case, output the case number first. Then output the
probability of player 1 winning the game rounded to 6 decimal places. <span
class=GramE>If the given partial game is impossible according to any of the
rules or data, output &quot;-1.000000&quot; instead.</span> Outputs will be checked
with special judge, so small precision errors will be ignored. Look at the
samples for exact format.</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Times New Roman","serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<table class=MsoNormalTable border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:1184;mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;mso-border-insideh:
 .5pt solid black;mso-border-insidev:.5pt solid black'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>
  <td width=319 valign=top style='width:239.4pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Sample
  Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=319 valign=top style='width:239.4pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Sample
  Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=319 valign=top style='width:239.4pt;border:solid black 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>4<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>WWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWW<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>1.0
  0.234<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>WWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWW<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0.3
  0.99<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>WWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWW<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoListParagraph style='margin-top:0cm;margin-right:0cm;margin-bottom:
  0cm;margin-left:18.0pt;margin-bottom:.0001pt;mso-add-space:auto;text-indent:
  -18.0pt;line-height:normal;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><b><span
  style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:
  "Courier New"'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>1.0<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  </span></span></span></b><![endif]><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;
  font-family:"Courier New"'>1.0<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>WL<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0.7
  0.3</span></b><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
  font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width=319 valign=top style='width:239.4pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid black 1.0pt;border-right:solid black 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid black .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid black .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid black .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Case
  1: 1.000000<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Case
  2: 1.000000<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Case
  3: -1.000000<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Case
  4: 0.444026</span></b><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
  10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'> <o:p></o:p></span></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Problem Setter: Sohel Hafiz, Special
Thanks: <span class=SpellE>Samee</span> <span class=SpellE>Zahur</span><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;
line-height:115%;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Illustration<br>
</span></b><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><br>
</span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;mso-bidi-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>Case 1: Player 1 has already won 20 points and next its his
serve. To win the next point (which is also the game point) he has a 1.0
probability of winning</span><b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
11.0pt;line-height:115%;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Case 2: Player 1 has already won 21
points and he won the game and so its 1.000000.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Case 3: The game should stop after 21
points, but the string has an extra W and makes this game invalid, so output
is -1.000000.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

</div>

</body>
